trans-unit.source: Consume an API app in Azure App Service from a .NET client
trans-unit.target: Consume an API app in Azure App Service from a .NET client

trans-unit.source: Learn how to consume an API app from a .NET client using the App Service SDK.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to consume an API app from a .NET client using the App Service SDK.

trans-unit.source: Consume an API app in Azure App Service from a .NET client
trans-unit.target: Consume an API app in Azure App Service from a .NET client

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows how to use the App Service SDK to write code that calls an API app that has been configured for Public (anonymous) or Public (authenticated) access level.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows how to use the App Service SDK to write code that calls an API app that has been configured for Public (anonymous) or Public (authenticated) access level.

trans-unit.source: The article covers the following example scenarios:
trans-unit.target: The article covers the following example scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Call a Public (anonymous) API app from a console application
trans-unit.target: Call a Public (anonymous) API app from a console application

trans-unit.source: Call a Public (authenticated) API app from a Windows Desktop application
trans-unit.target: Call a Public (authenticated) API app from a Windows Desktop application

trans-unit.source: Each of these tutorial sections is independent -- you can follow the instructions for the second scenario without having completed the steps for the first one.
trans-unit.target: Each of these tutorial sections is independent -- you can follow the instructions for the second scenario without having completed the steps for the first one.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to call an Internal API app, see Consume an internal API app from a .NET client.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to call an Internal API app, see Consume an internal API app from a .NET client.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: the tutorial assumes that you are familiar with how to create projects and add code to them in Visual Studio, and how to <link><linkText>manage API apps in the Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: the tutorial assumes that you are familiar with how to create projects and add code to them in Visual Studio, and how to <link><linkText>manage API apps in the Azure preview portal</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The project and code samples in this article are based on the API app project that you create, deploy, and protect in these articles:
trans-unit.target: The project and code samples in this article are based on the API app project that you create, deploy, and protect in these articles:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Create an API app</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Protect an API app</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Protect an API app</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: This tutorial requires version 2.6 or later of the Azure SDK for .NET.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial requires version 2.6 or later of the Azure SDK for .NET.

trans-unit.source: Unauthenticated call from a console application
trans-unit.target: Unauthenticated call from a console application

trans-unit.source: In this section you create a console application project and add code to it that calls an API app that doesn't require authentication.
trans-unit.target: In this section you create a console application project and add code to it that calls an API app that doesn't require authentication.

trans-unit.source: Set up the API app and create the project
trans-unit.target: Set up the API app and create the project

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already done so, follow the <link><linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title></link> to deploy the ContactsList sample project to an API app in your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already done so, follow the <link><linkText>Deploy an API app</linkText><title></title></link> to deploy the ContactsList sample project to an API app in your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: That tutorial directs you to set the access level in the Visual Studio publish dialog to Available to anyone, which is the same as Public (anonymous) in the portal.
trans-unit.target: That tutorial directs you to set the access level in the Visual Studio publish dialog to Available to anyone, which is the same as Public (anonymous) in the portal.

trans-unit.source: However, if you did the Protect an API app tutorial after that, the access level has been set to Public (authenticated), and in that case you need to change it as directed in the following step.
trans-unit.target: However, if you did the Protect an API app tutorial after that, the access level has been set to Public (authenticated), and in that case you need to change it as directed in the following step.

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, in the API app blade for the API app that you want to call, go to Settings > Application Settings and set Access level to Public (anonymous).
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, in the API app blade for the API app that you want to call, go to Settings > Application Settings and set Access level to Public (anonymous).

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create a console application project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create a console application project.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Add App Service SDK generated client code
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Add App Service SDK generated client code

trans-unit.source: Add code to call the API app
trans-unit.target: Add code to call the API app

trans-unit.source: To call the API app, all you have to do is create a client object and call methods on it, as in this example:
trans-unit.target: To call the API app, all you have to do is create a client object and call methods on it, as in this example:

trans-unit.source: Open Program.cs, and add the following code inside the Main method.
trans-unit.target: Open Program.cs, and add the following code inside the Main method.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Generation Complete</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Generation Complete</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Authenticated call from a Windows desktop application
trans-unit.target: Authenticated call from a Windows desktop application

trans-unit.source: In this section you create a Windows desktop application project and add code to it that calls an API app that requires authentication.
trans-unit.target: In this section you create a Windows desktop application project and add code to it that calls an API app that requires authentication.

trans-unit.source: Set up the API app and create the project
trans-unit.target: Set up the API app and create the project

trans-unit.source: Follow the Protect an API app tutorial to set up an API app with Public (authenticated) access level.
trans-unit.target: Follow the Protect an API app tutorial to set up an API app with Public (authenticated) access level.

trans-unit.source: In Visual Studio, create a Windows Forms desktop project.
trans-unit.target: In Visual Studio, create a Windows Forms desktop project.

trans-unit.source: In the form designer, add the following controls:
trans-unit.target: In the form designer, add the following controls:

trans-unit.source: A button control
trans-unit.target: A button control

trans-unit.source: A text box control
trans-unit.target: A text box control

trans-unit.source: A web browser control
trans-unit.target: A web browser control

trans-unit.source: Set the text box control to multi-line.
trans-unit.target: Set the text box control to multi-line.

trans-unit.source: Your form should look like the following example.
trans-unit.target: Your form should look like the following example.

trans-unit.source: Add App Service SDK generated client code
trans-unit.target: Add App Service SDK generated client code

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and select Add > Azure API App Client.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the project (not the solution) and select Add > Azure API App Client.

trans-unit.source: In the Add Azure API App Client dialog, click Download from Azure API App.
trans-unit.target: In the Add Azure API App Client dialog, click Download from Azure API App.

trans-unit.source: From the drop-down list, select the API app that you want to call, and then click OK.
trans-unit.target: From the drop-down list, select the API app that you want to call, and then click OK.

trans-unit.source: Add code to call the API app
trans-unit.target: Add code to call the API app

trans-unit.source: In the Azure preview portal, copy the URL for your API app's gateway.
trans-unit.target: In the Azure preview portal, copy the URL for your API app's gateway.

trans-unit.source: You'll use this value in the next step.
trans-unit.target: You'll use this value in the next step.

trans-unit.source: In Form1.cs source code, add the following code before the Form1() constructor, replacing the value for GATEWAY_URL with the value you copied in the previous step.
trans-unit.target: In Form1.cs source code, add the following code before the Form1() constructor, replacing the value for GATEWAY_URL with the value you copied in the previous step.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you include the trailing slash (/).
trans-unit.target: Make sure you include the trailing slash (/).

trans-unit.source: In the form designer, double-click the button to add a click handler, and then in the handler method add code to go to the login URL for the gateway, for example:
trans-unit.target: In the form designer, double-click the button to add a click handler, and then in the handler method add code to go to the login URL for the gateway, for example:

trans-unit.source: Replace "[authprovider]" with the code for the identity service provider that you configured in the gateway, for example, "aad", "twitter", "google", "microsoftaccount", or "facebook".
trans-unit.target: Replace "[authprovider]" with the code for the identity service provider that you configured in the gateway, for example, "aad", "twitter", "google", "microsoftaccount", or "facebook".

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Add a DocumentCompleted event handler for the web browser control, and add the following code to the handler method.
trans-unit.target: Add a DocumentCompleted event handler for the web browser control, and add the following code to the handler method.

trans-unit.source: The code you've added runs after the user logs in using the web browser control.
trans-unit.target: The code you've added runs after the user logs in using the web browser control.

trans-unit.source: After a successful login, the response URL contains the user ID and password.
trans-unit.target: After a successful login, the response URL contains the user ID and password.

trans-unit.source: The code extracts these values from the URL, provides them to the App Service client object, and then uses that object to create an API app client object.
trans-unit.target: The code extracts these values from the URL, provides them to the App Service client object, and then uses that object to create an API app client object.

trans-unit.source: You can then call the API by calling methods on this API app client object.
trans-unit.target: You can then call the API by calling methods on this API app client object.

trans-unit.source: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.
trans-unit.target: Press CTRL+F5 to run the application.

trans-unit.source: Click the button, and when the browser control displays a login page, enter the credentials of a user authorized to call the API app.
trans-unit.target: Click the button, and when the browser control displays a login page, enter the credentials of a user authorized to call the API app.

trans-unit.source: Azure authenticates you, and the application calls the API app and displays the response.
trans-unit.target: Azure authenticates you, and the application calls the API app and displays the response.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Server flow vs. client flow
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Server flow vs. client flow

trans-unit.source: The sample application illustrates <link><linkText>server flow</linkText><title></title></link>, which means the gateway gets the identity provider's access token.
trans-unit.target: The sample application illustrates <link><linkText>server flow</linkText><title></title></link>, which means the gateway gets the identity provider's access token.

trans-unit.source: For client flow, in which your client application gets the access token directly from the identity provider and sends it to the gateway, you call LoginAsync rather than SetCurrentUser.
trans-unit.target: For client flow, in which your client application gets the access token directly from the identity provider and sends it to the gateway, you call LoginAsync rather than SetCurrentUser.

trans-unit.source: The following code example assumes that you have the identity provider's access token in a string variable named providerAccessToken and the identity provider indicator ("aad", "microsoftaccount", "google", "twitter", or "facebook") in a string variable named idProvider:
trans-unit.target: The following code example assumes that you have the identity provider's access token in a string variable named providerAccessToken and the identity provider indicator ("aad", "microsoftaccount", "google", "twitter", or "facebook") in a string variable named idProvider:

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: This article has shown how to consume an API app from a .NET client, for API apps set to Public (authenticated) and Public (anonymous) access levels.
trans-unit.target: This article has shown how to consume an API app from a .NET client, for API apps set to Public (authenticated) and Public (anonymous) access levels.

trans-unit.source: For additional examples of code that calls an API app from .NET clients, download the <link><linkText>Azure Cards</linkText><title></title></link> sample application.
trans-unit.target: For additional examples of code that calls an API app from .NET clients, download the <link><linkText>Azure Cards</linkText><title></title></link> sample application.

trans-unit.source: For information about how to use authentication in API apps, see <link><linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For information about how to use authentication in API apps, see <link><linkText>Authentication for API apps and mobile apps in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title></link>.
